instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
Hello

Got this board liquid damage. Customer had already cleaned the board. Corroded RB631. Replaced resistor and also retraced a new line from RB631 pin2 to RB651pin2 as it's pad was missing. Also replaced QB631 due to signs of corrosion. Still won't power up. 
Found L6900/01 missing. Replaced. Still won't power up.
Took below measurements

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.2
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 5.17
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> - 5.17

So replaced all the CD3215C chips with exact chips numbers. Still have the same result. Any other suggestions or is this dead board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.2"
Are you sure about that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0 and no pulse
And yess, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.2. I rechecked to confirm on F7000 pin 2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: Post <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> - 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U9640</CHIP> voltages.
<SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> is shared by all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
One of them can pull it down if bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
I'm assuming you meant to type <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>. If so, here are measurements

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PMU_RSLOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: Can't find any data sheet for <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> - SLG4AP41183. Is this some sort of latch like an SR latch?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
Yes <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>, sorry for mystyping.
No datasheet needed it here.
Post EXACT voltage for its pin10 and previous signals mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PMU_RSLOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN_R</SIGNAL> - 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
Let me be more specific; looks like you didn't understand me.
Poste exact (two decimals) voltage for <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN_R</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL>.
We need to see which side of output resistors is pulled down.
If all are 0.0V, or <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN_R</SIGNAL> is the lowest, then change <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: I?ll get the measurements later today.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: All of them are reading 0.00v. Even after swapping out <CHIP>U6490</CHIP> from a donor board, still reading the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
Isn't <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>???
If has 3V at pins 1, 3, 4, then must have 3V at output pin 10.
Remove <RESISTOR>R6940</RESISTOR>/41 and check that; supposing a pull-up resistor is inside <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
Yeah, I meant <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>. I pulled <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> with the same readings on 1, 3, 4 and 10. Also, there is no <CHIP>U6941</CHIP> on this board. 
I agree with you that pin 10 should have 3v. It's possible the replacement chip I pulled from a donor board is also bad. Unfortunately I can't find a replacement online anywhere. Going to have to see if I can find another donor board or a board that has this chip on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
"there is no <CHIP>U6941</CHIP> on this board"
I never mentioned such chip!
---Remove <RESISTOR>R6940</RESISTOR>/41---

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: Sorry both that. I?ve been looking at this board for so long, I?m even seeing it in my dreams. Will get you those numbers soon.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: Pulled <RESISTOR>R6940</RESISTOR>/41, still 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: Then is <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: Yeah I kinda figured it was. Currently searching for possible substitute. Can?t find the chip anywhere without pulling from a donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
If think better, missing "_L" from <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> signal name should mean 0V is correct level.
I was confused because of the name used on old boards for <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal.
In both cases, reset should be disabled.
That means 0V now and 3V for old boards; mea culpa...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message:
So I start checking all the signals on the usb-c chip and found <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> that kept bouncing about. Found a failed coil, L6813. This finally restored the 20v but same issue I'm having on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, its not powering up still. This board also has the T2 chip.

So far:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0.0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5v
threads.message: Look at the recent post about <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and check the same mentioned signals and voltages.

Try and comment...

threads.message:
Below readings gotten from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. COuldn't do much testing as customer can't wait anymore, so had to return it. Also, there is no power to the USB-c for the ethernet adapter to work, so don't think connecting to apple serve to download the T2 data, as state in the document, would work. Oh well. But thanks for all the assist.
